phrase.item: Shogen is a holiday for farmers.
The farmer, when shogen is near, mills wheat (for bread).
One day before the holiday, they make the new year logs and that day make (put) shushp (a traditional meal)
In the morning of shogen holiday, they take four or five thick spikes and tie brooms at the top oh the sticks.
The woman will sweep the house and the ceiling with that.
She pours water on herself, takes shower then takes pea flour in her hand and stamps it on all the walls and pillars. That's called ptik.
Some people dip their fingers into flour and make circles on the wall, thats called "kids and lambs".
They make a loaf of bread, a big one, you put it in the middle of the oven,
then without blowing together with the ash,they stamp it on the wall, then a symbol of the bread stays on the wall.
After cleaning the house and putting flour on the walls (ptik) they will start cooking food, it's called tajdedaji
the after cleaning food (tajdedaji) is only served for distant relatives or close by neighbours.
Everyone makes food of their choice, some may make bat (traditional food made of butter and flour), bread or fried eggs.
Then visiting each house will start. (its called xonagashtak)
In visiting each other's house, all men and children, when the guests have arrived in the village, they take them from house to house.
Whenever they reach any house, each person take the branch outside the house and says:
Los los happy spring holiday (shogun). I brought a throne, I brought fortune, I brought piles of wealth and the wealth of Ishkoshim, I brought.

word.item: two pillars at the entrance to a house

phrase.item: When they enter, at the threshold, one person takes a bowl with flour and whoever comes inside the house, he puts flour on the shoulder (of the guest).
The person who sprinkle the flour must stay on the right side.
Then that person will be served with special dishes like: Shirberenj (traditional food made of milk and rice), Shula ( made of water and rice) and meat.
They bring a big plate in front of them.
Whether anyone eats or not, that's the tradition.
When all the dishes are taken away to the kitchen side, caliph seats in the main place and recites prayers
Successful work, successful time, a blessed spring holiday
May one of us be thousands, may thousands be countless, for the sake of Ajdari Karror (holy person's name)
New year, new month, may we be always together without sorrow.
God is great!
When that night is passed, next day in the morning one person sits on the donkey facing backwards and enters the house.
He also says the same: "los los congratulation with spring holiday!"
Then they give the donkey barley and rub his forehead with shushp or a mixture of flour and water.
they sprinkle ptik on the donkey and take him outside.
Those thick sticks which were brought before, they take off the skin and hang them inside the house without touching them the rest of the time.
When the time comes to take lambs to the grass, at that moment the woods will be burned.
They burn the wood and make grilled wheat with it.
When shogen holiday comes that time all new lambs go to eat grass.
In the day of shogen, after going to each other house, they take out the "egg robber".
They take wheat.
They make bulls aware that will do sowing
two-three rounds
From that wheat which was taken for sowing, everyone from each family takes a fistfull and throws it from the chimney to the house, that means seeds are out.

If they first throw wheat from the chimney, that means crops will become more, but if a lady throws shushpay (traditional food) with spoon from the chimney first thengi (useless part of wheat) will become more.
Our shogun (holiday) has a mark.
In that marked stone, it gives the sign of Amal (first month of Spring), our shogun holiday.
We confirm the time (with khalifa) and put clothes outside.
When we come back we have some tea and then the men go out.
Ladies take the broom and first they clean the chimney.
then they start cleaning the whole house.
when they finish cleaning they throw the trash far away
they come home take shower and then the men come.
ladies sprikle flour ( on their right shoulder)
The men come saying: "Los los, a throne we brought, fortune we brought, wealth of Ishkoshim, friends we brought."
"Happy spring holiday (Shogun) to all."
Everyone holds shogun sticks in their hands.
Then when they sprinkle the flour, guests will be served with bread. (Special bread made only in shogun holiday, called shogun qemoch)
Whoever makes bat (traditional food made of butter or oil and flour), they serve it as well and then they start going to each other house.
kaʈən is questionable here.
In each house the caliph recite prayers and wishes them a happy spring holiday.
"May one becomes thousands and thousands become countless, on the name of Haydari Qaror!"
New year, new month, may we be always together and be happy.
"God is great!"
Then we leave.
We take the seed and sow it.
Children take from those seeds and bring them home and put (drop) them into the chimney.
The women take a spoon with a rolling pin and throw it to the roof.
If they throw first, there will be a lot of wheat, if they throw the spoons first then there wll be a lot of butter.
Then our sowing begins.
Then, next, when it becomes bright, a man first gets up from his place and brings a donkey and enters the house from outside and says, "Los, los, I brought a fortune, I brought wealth and friends."
"Happy Shogun (Spring) holiday!"
then they make the donkey's forehead wet and sprinkle flour on it.
The donkey will be given barley and people will be served with shirbirinj (traditional food made of milk and rice).
He eats it, they pray again saying "fatai kor, fatoi ruzgor" and then start sowing.
